c74object.name: bach.istruct
c74object.digest: Get the interval structure pitch-class set
c74object.description: Reports the interval structure of a pitch-class set, i.e. the list

inlet.description: A complex tree of pitch-class sets is also accepted.

outlet.description: The interval structure of the incoming pitch-class set. If a complex tree of pitch-class sets was input, the output is a tree of interval structures, mirroring it in shape.

objarg.name: modulo
objarg.description: In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.

objarg.name: autosort
objarg.description: Sort automatically the points in the pitch-class set before reporting the interval structure (by default it is set).

method.name: bang
method.description: Gets the interval structure of the most recently received input data.

method.name: int
method.description:
An integer in the right inlet will set the modulo.
In the standard framework, the modulo is the number of subdivision of the octave (represented as a circle). The modulo is thus the number of points in this circle. The default and most common modulo is 12 (corresponding to semitonal grid). Modulo 24 is the quartertone grid, and so on.

method.name: llll
method.digest: Get interval structure of pitch-class set
method.description: In the first inlet, a pitch-class set will report its interval structure

attribute.name: autosort
attribute.description: Sort automatically the points in the pitch-class set before reporting the interval structure (by default it is set).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

entry.name: Inlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: Pitch-class set(s). A complex tree of pitch-class sets is also accepted.

entry.name: Outlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: Interval structure(s). The interval structure of the incoming pitch-class set. If a complex tree of pitch-class sets was input, the output is a tree of interval structures, mirroring it in shape.
